subtitle: Huitzilopochtli- "Hummingbird of the South" / "Left-Handed Hummingbird"
name: Aztec - Huitzilopochtli

listDisplay.primary: Aztec - Huitzilopochtli - Huitzilopochtli- "Hummingbird of the South" / "Left-Handed Hummingbird"
listDisplay.expandedContent:
The patron god of the Mexica people, Huitzilopochtli was the solar deity of war and sacrifice who guided his
                people from their legendary homeland of Aztlan to found the great city of Tenochtitlan. His daily battle
                against darkness required the nourishment of human hearts and blood, making him the driving force behind
                Aztec expansionism and ritual sacrifice.

periods.description: Huitzilopochtli guided the Mexica from their legendary homeland through divine mandate
His sign (eagle on cactus) indicated location for city founding on Lake Texcoco
Became state cult deity, central to imperial ideology and military expansion

tonalpohualli.description: Birth day of Huitzilopochtli in Aztec calendar
Major festival of Huitzilopochtli with human sacrifice

calendarAssociations.significance: Solar deity requiring nourishment (nextlaoaliztli) through human sacrifice

preColumbian.name: Codex Tovar
preColumbian.content: Military campaigns and divine guidance to Tenochtitlan

preColumbian.name: Codex Mendoza (Tribute Roll)
preColumbian.content: Huitzilopochtli temple (Templo Mayor) as political-religious center

colonialSpanish.name: Florentine Codex (Book 1)
colonialSpanish.author: Bernardino de Sahagún
colonialSpanish.content: Detailed account of Toxcatl festival and human sacrifice ritual

colonialSpanish.name: Historia de las Indias
colonialSpanish.author: Bartolomé de las Casas
colonialSpanish.content: Spanish colonial perspective on Aztec religious practices

colonialSpanish.name: Crónica Mexicana
colonialSpanish.author: Fernando Alvarado Tezozomoc
colonialSpanish.content: Indigenous account of Huitzilopochtli's role in Mexica history

nativeNahuatl.name: Anales de Cuauhtitlán
nativeNahuatl.content: Mythological birth and deeds of Huitzilopochtli

primary.name: Templo Mayor (Tenochtitlan)
primary.description: Great Temple shared dual shrine for Huitzilopochtli (south) and Tlaloc (north)
primary.findings: Sacrificial stones, warrior remains, ceramic vessels with god's likeness

secondary.name: Tenayuca
secondary.description: Twin pyramid temple with evidence of Huitzilopochtli cult

secondary.name: Malinalco
secondary.description: Temple dedicated to military orders (Eagles and Jaguars)

primary.purpose: Nourish the sun god for daily journey across sky
Ensure solar rebirth and military strength

sacrificialRites.significance: Cosmic necessity - sun required chalchiuhatl (precious water = blood) to continue its path

militaryAssociations.title: Divine patron of Mexica state
militaryAssociations.role: Justified imperial warfare as cosmic necessity
militaryAssociations.symbolism: Eagle symbolism connected to military orders (Cuauhtin - Eagles)
militaryAssociations.expansionism: Aztec expansion (1428-1521) linked to fulfilling Huitzilopochtli's mandate

culturalTransmission.preColumbian: Likely evolved from earlier Toltec solar cults with Nahua traditions
culturalTransmission.colonialAdaptation: Spanish friars documented extensively but condemned practices as demonic
culturalTransmission.modernNahua: Contemporary Nahua communities maintain modified veneration in syncretized practices

_methodologyNotes: Calendar associations verified against primary codex sources
Codex sources include primary Spanish colonial records and native nahuatl/maya texts
Archaeological sites documented from excavation reports and academic publications
Sacrificial rituals documented from Florentine Codex and validated against archaeological evidence
